column1: Sentence
He joined ATK Launch Systems Group in 2006 as Vice President of Advanced Programs.
Kent Rominger was born in Del Norte, Colorado.
He graduated from Del Norte High School in 1974.
He has been awarded the Defense Superior Service Medal, the Distinguished Flying Cross, the Defense Meritorious Service Medal and the NASA Distinguished Service Medal.
In 2000 He was nominated and inducted into the Colorado Aviation Hall of Fame.
Rominger received his commission through the Aviation Reserve Officer Candidate (AVROC) Program in 1979, and was designated a Naval Aviator in September 1980.
While assigned to VF-2, Rominger attended the Navy Fighter Weapons School (TOPGUN).
He has logged over 5,000 flying hours in over 35 types of aircraft and 685 carrier landings.
Selected by NASA in March 1992, Rominger reported to the Johnson Space Center in August 1992.
He completed one year of training and qualified for assignment as a pilot on future Space Shuttle flight crews.
Rominger was initially assigned to work technical issues for the Astronaut Office Operations Development Branch.
He also served as Chief of the Astronaut Office Shuttle Operations Branch, and Deputy Director, Flight Crew Operations.
A veteran of five space flights, Rominger has logged over 1,600 hours in space.
He and his wife Mary Sue have one child.
STS-73 in Space Shuttle Columbia (October 20 to November 5, 1995) was the second United States Microgravity Laboratory mission.
The mission focused on materials science, biotechnology, combustion science, fluid dynamics, and numerous scientific experiments housed in the pressurized Spacelab module.

column2: The free-flying WSF created a super vacuum in its wake and grew thin film wafers for use in semiconductors and other high-tech electrical components.

column1: The ORFEUS instruments, mounted on the reusable Shuttle Pallet Satellite, studied the origin and makeup of stars.
The mission was accomplished in 189 Earth orbits, traveling 4.7 million miles in 11 days, 20 hours and 27 minutes.
The mission was completed in 187 Earth orbits, traveling 4.9 million miles in 11 days, 21 hours and 30 minutes.
